Award.AwardTitle: Effect of seamount subduction on fault geometry and rupture propagation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Christine Regalla has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a research and education plan while at McGill University in Montreal, Canada. She will investigate the role of variable fault geometry and strength in the vicinity of subducted seamounts on the nucleation and propagation of megathrust ruptures. This work has direct implications for understanding processes controlling the nucleation and maximum magnitude of large megathrust earthquakes. Subduction zones generate the world's largest earthquakes and tsunamis and the limits on earthquake size depend in part on the geometry of the fault boundary between the two plates. Rough spots and bumps such as seamounts on the down-going plate can affect the degree of locking along the plate boundary fault and modulate the magnitude and distribution of plate boundary slip during earthquakes. Results from this project can be applied to seismic hazard assessments to help estimate maximum rupture area and moment magnitude at megathrusts with subducted seamounts. This project will create opportunities for knowledge sharing between field and modeling-based research groups, and will provide valuable professional development for Regalla as an early-career scientist. In addition, this project will involve undergraduate student researchers, thereby providing opportunities for Regalla to develop educational and mentoring skills, and provide hands-on research opportunities for undergraduate students.

Although the subduction of seamounts is common, there is considerable debate as to whether seamounts act as sites of earthquake nucleation or barriers that impede rupture propagation. This work will combine analyses of field outcrops of ancient plate boundary thrust faults that were active during seamount subduction with finite element models of dynamic rupture to evaluate proposed models of earthquake rupture. This project will provide the first known descriptions of the physical properties of the subduction thrust in locations where ancient seamounts have subducted to seismogenic depths, and will provide observationally-based model constraints for fault geometry and strength parameters in numeric simulations of rupture involving subducted seamounts. Results of this work will provide information on the structural accommodation of subducted seamounts and their control on earthquake rupture propagation.

The fellowship is being co-funded with the Office of Integrated and International Activities - International Science and Engineering

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project had two sets of outcomes related to: a) documenting the geometry, composition, and deformation mechanisms in megathrust fault zones associated with the subduction of seamounts and other seafloor topographic highs, and b) providing evidence for Holocene paleoseismicity along crustal faults on Vancouver Island, in the forearc of the Cascadia subduction zone.

Mapping and microstructural analysis of ancient seamount fault contacts in Cascadia and central California have provided first observations of the geometry and deformation mechanisms that operate in convergent plate boundaries when seamounts are subducted.  Seamount subduction is a common occurrence in subduction zones, but the role of seamounts in modulating subduction zone seismicity is debated.  Our field observations suggest that both discrete and structurally complex faults zone exist at seamount thrust contacts.  These data suggest that the wide variability is seismologic observations at modern subducted seamount may arise from variations in the structural style of the decollement.

Geomorphic and structural mapping on Vancouver Island has led to the discovery that several ancient subduction and forearc fault systems have become reactivated in the modern stress field and accommodate  seismogenesis. ­­ We have documented three Holocene earthquakes on the Leech River fault, which was not previously classified as active.  The fault runs through Victoria, the capitol of British Columbia, two hydro electric dams, and near several water supply reservoirs.  Our characterization of the seismic history of the Leech River fault suggests that there is a network of currently unmapped active faults in southwestern Canada. 

 

Broader Impacts:

These projects have led to the training of one female post-doctoral researcher, a chapter in the dissertation of one PhD student, field training opportunities for two additional PhD students (one female), and research and field training opportunities for six undergraduate students (five female) at two universities (McGill University and Boston University). Results from our mapping of subduction complexes in California have been used as the bases for a project in an undergraduate structural geology course at Boston University and as the basis for a field trip at the 2016 Structural Geology and Tectonics Forum.  Lastly, our documentation of active faulting and Holocene seismicity on southern Vancouver Island provide data that are being used to inform local seismic hazard models.  Our findings have been communicated to local academic, government, and private entities in British Columbia, Canada, and has been featured in several Vancouver region newspaper articles.
